translated: The Chronicle of the Buddhas
The Chronicle of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara
“Having fed the Leader of the World,
together with the Saṅgha,
they went for refuge to him,
to the Teacher Dīpaṅkara.
In going for refuge, some
the Tathāgata established,
in the five precepts,
in the tenfold virtue, and beyond.
To some he gave the state of a monk,
the four fruits of the highest state;
to some, in the unsurpassed Dhamma,
he gave the analytical knowledges.
To some, the bull among men gave
the eight excellent attainments;
to some, the three knowledges,
he wished for the six higher knowledges.
By that means, the Great Sage

analyzed: ovadati mahā muni  tena vitthārikam āsi
translated: instructed the people;🔽by that, the Dispensation of the Lord of the World
became widespread.🔽The one named Dīpaṅkara,
with shoulders like a great bull,
liberated many people,
and released them from the lower realms.
Seeing people to be instructed,
even at a distance of a hundred thousand leagues,
the Great Sage, having gone there in an instant,
instructed them.
At the first assembly, the Buddha
awakened a hundred and twenty koṭis;
At the second knowledge the Lord
awakened ninety koṭis of beings.🔽And when the Buddha preached the Law
in the abode of the gods,
ninety thousand koṭis of beings
attained the third knowledge.
Three times there were assemblies
of the disciples of the Master Dīpaṅkara.
The first assembly consisted of a hundred thousand koṭis,
the second of eighty thousand.🔽Again, when the Victorious One, the Jina,
had retired to the solitude of the Nārada Peak,🔽a hundred thousand koṭis of men,
free from the corruptions and pure,
came together.
At the time when the Great Hero,
the Great Sage, the Great Seer,
the Great Nāga, the Great Being,
the Great Sage, the Great Seer,
the Great Nāga, the Great Being,
the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,

analyzed: vitthārikam bāhujañña  iddham phītam ahū tadā
translated: the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,
the Great Sage, the Great Seer,

analyzed: sāsanam su visodhita  cattāri sata sahassāni
translated: the Great Nāga, the Great Being,
the Great Sage, the Great Seer,

original: Dīpaṅkaraṁ lokaviduṁ,🔽parivārenti sabbadā.🔽Ye keci tena samayena,
analyzed: dīpaṅkaram loka vidu  parivārenti sabbadā  ye keci tena samayena
translated: the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,🔽the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great Seer,
the Great Nāga, the Great Being,🔽the Great Sage, the Great
The disciples who are not yet perfect in mind,
are reproached by them.
The well-taught doctrine,
by the noble ones like this;
By those whose corruptions are destroyed, who are stainless,
always shines forth.
The city named Rammavatī,
the noble one named Sudeva;
Sumedhā was his mother,
of the Teacher Dīpaṅkara.
For ten thousand years,
he dwelt in the house;
Geese, cranes, and peacocks,
were the three best palaces.
Three hundred thousand,
women were adorned;
The woman named Padumā,
the son with the shoulder of a bull.
Seeing the four signs,
he departed by elephant;
With the sound of Anūna,
the Victor went forth.
Having gone forth,
the sage attained the higher mind;
Being requested by Brahmā,
the great sage Dīpaṅkara.
The Great Hero set the Wheel rolling,
in the Nandārāma, in the Sirīgha;
Sitting at the root of the Sirīsa tree,
he made the destruction of the sectarians.
Sumaṅgala and Tissa,
were his chief disciples;
Sāgata was his attendant,🔽

analyzed: dīpaṅkarassa satthunaḥ  nandā ca iva sunandā ca
translated: The attendant of Dīpaṅkara was named Sāgata.
Nandā and Sunandā were the chief female disciples;
The Bodhi tree of that Exalted One
is said to have been a pipphali tree.

analyzed: ahesum aggu paṭṭhakā  sirimā koṇā upaṭṭhikā
translated: Tapussabhallikā were the chief male lay disciples;

analyzed: dīpaṅkarassa satthunaḥ  asīti hattham ubbedhaḥ  dīpaṅkaraḥ mahā muni
translated: Sirimā and Koṇā were the chief female lay disciples of Dīpaṅkara.
The Great Sage Dīpaṅkara was eighty cubits in height;

analyzed: sālarāja ava phullitaḥ  sata sahassa vassāni
translated: He shone like a lamp, like a blossoming sāla tree.
The lifespan of that Great Sage was one hundred thousand years;
For that length of time he remained,
and delivered many people.
Having caused the Good Dhamma to shine,
and delivered the great people,
like a mass of fire that has burned out,
he was extinguished together with his disciples.

original: Sā ca iddhi so ca yaso,
analyzed: sā ca id hi sā ca
translated: That psychic power, that glory,
and those wheel-marks on the soles of the feet,
all that has disappeared,
are not all conditioned things empty?
The Victor Dīpaṅkara, the Teacher,
was extinguished in the Nandārāma;
Right there his Victor-Thūpa
was thirty yojanas high.”
The lineage of the Lord Dipankara is the first.
